greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(1) = 1; then the smallest number different from its predecessor such that the n-th partial product is an n-th power.
comment: Or "such that the geometric mean of the first n terms is an integer." (Without the "different from its predecessor" requirement, the trivial sequence 1,4,2,2,2,2,2,... would have resulted.)
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..2209
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (0, 10, 0, -16).
mathematica: CoefficientList[Series[x (1 + 4 x - 8 x^2 - 8 x^3)/(1 - 10 x^2 + 16 x^4), {x, 0, 31}], x] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Nov 24 2017 *)
results.author: _Amarnath Murthy_, Oct 19 2002
